abstract: Masked gunmen attack Paris headquarters of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, killing 12 people and traumatizing city; police carry out manhunt for suspects Said and Cherif Kouachi, while third suspect Hamyd Mourad turns himself in; reports that Kouachi brothers were born in Paris raises fear of homegrown terrorists and distrust of local Muslims.
lead_paragraph: Hamyd Mourad, 18, suspected in an assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, walked into a police station northeast of Paris and gave himself up. The other suspects are two brothers, Said and Chérif Kouachi.

byline.contributor: Aurelien Breeden and Laure Fourquet contributed reporting from Paris, and Michael S. Schmidt from Washington.
byline.original: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

snippet: Hamyd Mourad, 18, suspected in an assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, walked into a police station northeast of Paris and gave himself up. The other suspects are two brothers, Said and Chérif Kouachi.

headline.main: Terrorists Strike Charlie Hebdo Newspaper in Paris, Leaving 12 Dead
headline.print_headline: Terrorists Strike Paris Newspaper, Leaving 12 Dead
headline.sub: One Suspect Surrenders; Police Organize Manhunt for 2 Others
